title: Alessandra Martines
text:
Alessandra Martines (born 19 September 1963) is an <a href="Italians">Italian</a>-<a href="French%20people">French</a> dancer and actress mainly working in the <a href="British%20English">English</a>, <a href="French%20language">French</a> and <a href="Italian%20language">Italian</a> speaking-worlds. She started young in <a href="ballet">ballet</a> on major <a href="opera">opera</a> stages in <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>, <a href="France">France</a>, the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> and then <a href="Italy">Italy</a> before becoming a lead on <a href="television">television</a> for <a href="RAI">RAI</a> captured ballets and entertainment shows (the Italian national <a href="public%20broadcasting">public broadcasting</a>) in the <a href="1980s">eighties</a>. She is primarily known for portraying the main role in the cult "<a href="Fantaghir%C3%B2%20series">Fantaghirò series</a>" consisting of five films (1991-1996) still regularly rerun across <a href="europe">europe</a> as of 2020 and her work in <a href="Auteur%20cinema">auteur</a> productions such as nine films by <a href="Claude%20Lelouch">Claude Lelouch</a> to whom she was married until 2009. She was awarded numerous prizes including the Best Actress <a href="Telegatto">Telegatto</a> for "<a href="The%20Cave%20of%20the%20Golden%20Rose">The Cave of the Golden Rose</a>" (1991), the <a href="Grolla%20d%27oro">Grolla d'oro</a> for "" (2005), the <a href="Silver%20Hugo">Silver Hugo</a> for Best Actress at the <a href="Chicago%20International%20Film%20Festival">Chicago International Film Festival</a> (1998) for "<a href="Chance%20or%20Coincidence">Chance or Coincidence</a>", the Diamanti al Cinema Award in <a href="Cannes">Cannes</a> (2007) or the 2009 European <a href="Golden%20Globe%20Awards">Golden Globe</a> in <a href="Rome">Rome</a>. In 2008, she was made Knight of the <a href="Ordre%20national%20du%20M%C3%A9rite">Ordre national du Mérite</a> awarded by the <a href="President%20of%20the%20French%20Republic">President of the French Republic</a>. She received the lifetime achievement Kineo Award at the <a href="71st%20Venice%20International%20Film%20Festival">71st Venice International Film Festival</a> in 2014.
Early life.
Second cousin of <a href="Carla%20Bruni">Carla Bruni</a> and <a href="Valeria%20Bruni%20Tedeschi">Valeria Bruni Tedeschi</a>, she moved to <a href="France">France</a> with her family at the age of five. As a teenager, she enrolled at the <a href="Conservatoire%20de%20Paris">Conservatoire de Paris</a> where she also studies <a href="solfeggio">solfeggio</a>, history and theory of dance and <a href="classical%20music">classical music</a> and <a href="dance">dance</a>. 
Career.
Martines debuted at a very young age as a dancer at the <a href="Zurich%20Opera%20House">Zurich Opera House</a> in 1972. After some time working in the United States, including the <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a> City Ballet, she moved to <a href="Rome">Rome</a> where she worked at the <a href="Teatro%20dell%27Opera%20di%20Roma">Teatro dell'Opera</a>. In 1985 she began her collaboration with <a href="RAI">RAI</a>, with the lunchtime chat / quiz show "Pronto, chi gioca?"; she later gained great popularity with the Saturday Night shows "<a href="Fantastico%20%28variety%20show%29">Fantastico</a>" and "Europa Europa", and then for her portrayal of Princess Fantaghirò in the "<a href="Fantaghir%C3%B2%20series">Fantaghirò series</a>".
In cinema, she is best known and her interpretations under the direction of her ex-husband, the French director <a href="Claude%20Lelouch">Claude Lelouch</a>, in several movies including "<a href="Les%20Mis%C3%A9rables%20%281995%20film%29">Les Misérables</a>" and "<a href="And%20now...%20Ladies%20and%20Gentlemen">And now... Ladies and Gentlemen</a>". She also starred on stage, remarkably in "L'appartamento" by <a href="Franca%20Valeri">Franca Valeri</a>.
Personal life.
Martines has a daughter, called Stella Lelouch, with husband <a href="Claude%20Lelouch">Claude Lelouch</a> who she was married to from 1995–2009. In 2012 at the age of 49, she had a son, Hugo, with her partner since 2008 <a href="Cyril%20Descours">Cyril Descours</a> who is 20 years her junior.
